pullRequest.title: Stash the right number of arguments for invokehandle/invokedynamic
pullRequest.bodyText:
If the transition target is invokehandle/invokedynamic, the arguments to
be stashed are those already pushed onto the stack before generating the
bytecode, regardless of the number of arguments needed by the generated
call.
The generated call requires one (in resolved case) or two (in unresolved
case) implicit arguments, so we need to substract them to get the actual
number of arguments needed.
The reason why we don't need to stash the implicit arguments is because
when we transition to the VM, VM will push the implicit argument onto
the stack which is part of the behavior of the
invokehandle/invokedynamic bytecode.
Signed-off-by: Liqun Liu liqunl@ca.ibm.com

beforeCommit.message:
Stash the right number of arguments for invokehandle/invokedyhamic

invokehandle/invokedynamic bytecode implicitly push an object from side
table as the last argument of the call. This is part of the behavior of
the bytecode in Openjdk MethodHandle implementation. The object should
not be stashed.

Signed-off-by: Liqun Liu <liqunl@ca.ibm.com>

afterCommit.message:
Stash the right number of arguments for invokehandle/invokedyhamic

invokehandle/invokedynamic bytecode implicitly push an object from side
table as the last argument of the call. This is part of the behavior of
the bytecode in Openjdk MethodHandle implementation. The object should
not be stashed.

The unresolved case will have one more implicit argument pushed onto the
stack, as the MemberName from side table is unknown, the target method
is not known at compile time, thus, the JIT uses
MethodHandle.linkToStatic to represent the call. linkToStatic expects
the last argument to be MemberName object.

Signed-off-by: Liqun Liu <liqunl@ca.ibm.com>

beforeCommit.message:
Stash the right number of arguments for invokehandle/invokedyhamic

invokehandle/invokedynamic bytecode implicitly push an object from side
table as the last argument of the call. This is part of the behavior of
the bytecode in Openjdk MethodHandle implementation. The object should
not be stashed.

The unresolved case will have one more implicit argument pushed onto the
stack, as the MemberName from side table is unknown, the target method
is not known at compile time, thus, the JIT uses
MethodHandle.linkToStatic to represent the call. linkToStatic expects
the last argument to be MemberName object.

Signed-off-by: Liqun Liu <liqunl@ca.ibm.com>

afterCommit.message:
Stash the right number of arguments for invokehandle/invokedyhamic

invokehandle/invokedynamic bytecode implicitly push an object from side
table as the last argument of the call. This is part of the behavior of
the bytecode in Openjdk MethodHandle implementation. The object should
not be stashed.

The unresolved case will have one more implicit argument pushed onto the
stack, as the MemberName from side table is unknown, the target method
is not known at compile time, thus, the JIT uses
MethodHandle.linkToStatic to represent the call. linkToStatic expects
the last argument to be MemberName object.

Signed-off-by: Liqun Liu <liqunl@ca.ibm.com>

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1672,6 +1674,36 @@ TR_J9ByteCodeIlGenerator::stashArgumentsForOSR(TR_J9ByteCode byteCode)
    TR::MethodSymbol *symbol = symRef->getSymbol()->castToMethodSymbol();
    int32_t numArgs = symbol->getMethod()->numberOfExplicitParameters() + (symbol->isStatic() ? 0 : 1);
 
+#if defined(J9VM_OPT_OPENJDK_METHODHANDLE)
+   // invokehandle/invokedynamic bytecode implicitly push an object from side
+   // table as the last argument of the call. This is part of the behavior of
+   // the bytecode in Openjdk MethodHandle implementation. The object should
+   // not be stashed.
+   // The unresolved case will have one more implicit argument pushed onto the stack,
+   // as the MemberName from side table is unknown, the target method is not known at
+   // compile time, thus, the JIT uses MethodHandle.linkToStatic to represent the call.
+   // MethodHandle.linkToStatic expects the last argument to be MemberName object
+   //
+   // Resolved case:
+   // adapter(arg1, arg2, ..., argN, appendixObject)
+   // Unresolved case:
+   // MethodHandle.linkToStatic(arg1, arg2, ..., argN, appendixObject, MemberName)
+   //
+   // Notice that we always generate a resolved call, thus we use unresolvedInCP to tell
+   // us whehter the side table entry is resolved

nodes.bodyText: Can you also make it clear in the comment here that the MemberName object isn't being stashed either.  At least that's what I think is happening based on the code below.

    TR::MethodSymbol *symbol = symRef->getSymbol()->castToMethodSymbol();
    int32_t numArgs = symbol->getMethod()->numberOfExplicitParameters() + (symbol->isStatic() ? 0 : 1);
 
+#if defined(J9VM_OPT_OPENJDK_METHODHANDLE)
+   // invokehandle/invokedynamic bytecode implicitly push an object from side
+   // table as the last argument of the call. This is part of the behavior of
+   // the bytecode in Openjdk MethodHandle implementation. The object should
+   // not be stashed.
+   // The unresolved case will have one more implicit argument pushed onto the stack,
+   // as the MemberName from side table is unknown, the target method is not known at
+   // compile time, thus, the JIT uses MethodHandle.linkToStatic to represent the call.
+   // MethodHandle.linkToStatic expects the last argument to be MemberName object

commit.message:
Stash the right number of arguments for invokehandle/invokedynamic

If the transition target is invokehandle/invokedynamic, the arguments to
be stashed are those already pushed onto the stack before generating the
bytecode, regardless of the number of arguments needed by the generated
call.

The generated call requires one (in resolved case) or two (in unresolved
case) implicit arguments, so we need to substract them to get the actual
number of arguments needed.

The reason why we don't need to stash the implicit arguments is because
when we transition to the VM, VM will push the implicit argument onto
the stack which is part of the behavior of the
invokehandle/invokedynamic bytecode.

Signed-off-by: Liqun Liu <liqunl@ca.ibm.com>

beforeCommit.message:
Stash the right number of arguments for invokehandle/invokedyhamic

invokehandle/invokedynamic bytecode implicitly push an object from side
table as the last argument of the call. This is part of the behavior of
the bytecode in Openjdk MethodHandle implementation. The object should
not be stashed.

The unresolved case will have one more implicit argument pushed onto the
stack, as the MemberName from side table is unknown, the target method
is not known at compile time, thus, the JIT uses
MethodHandle.linkToStatic to represent the call. linkToStatic expects
the last argument to be MemberName object.

Signed-off-by: Liqun Liu <liqunl@ca.ibm.com>

If the transition target is invokehandle/invokedynamic, the arguments to

number of arguments needed.

The reason why we don't need to stash the implicit arguments is because
when we transition to the VM, VM will push the implicit argument onto
the stack which is part of the behavior of the
invokehandle/invokedynamic bytecode.

Signed-off-by: Liqun Liu <liqunl@ca.ibm.com>
